blocks.text: PRINCE SANTANA (33), Puerto Rican, thousand-yard stares you down. His eyes, twin ice-picks. No blink. No break.
This is not the guy you want to be trading hard looks with.
But it's not you he's looking at. He blinks --
Looks up at the PALE NEON CROSS above the doorway. Looks down at the MAN kneeling before him, prostrate.
He exhales. Icy stare locked in place, he looks down at the AUTOMATIC in his own hand, its heft comfortable. Familiar.
THE (PRE LAP) BLAST OF A CAR HORN snaps him out of it --
Prince, driving, sees a ghetto-fab SUV in the rearview, impatient driver glaring. He looks front -- green light.
Hits the gas, zips past a schoolyard decorated with an OLD GRAFFITI MURAL. Reaches the corner as the light flicks --
Red.
He looks over at the passenger seat, sees -- THE AUTOMATIC. Tucks it under the seat, makes sure it's secure. Satisfied, he looks out the window, and sees --
A TEENAGE MOM push a baby stroller across the street, her Philadelphia Phillies cap matching the baby's red sneakers.
He stares. She stares back, eyes locked. Until --
A POLICE CRUISER SCREECHES UP -- COPS JUMP OUT, GUNS POINTED!
TURN IT OFF! TURN ITHANDS, ASSHOLE! SHOW ME THE FUCK OFF!YOUR FUCKIN' HANDS!
ANOTHER and then ANOTHER, and then ONE MORE POLICE CAR arrive. A GANG OF COPS CIRCLE HIS CAR -- all locked and loaded and ready to make the 11 o' clock news.
Prince cuts the engine, drops the keys out the window, and watches the red and blue gumballs dance in his side mirror.
Ice cold stare. No blink. No break. No... nothing.
Definitely not the guy you want to be trading hard looks with.

But if you've got the rocks to look a little deeper, maybe an indignity or two beyond the retinas, you'll see that a long- smoldering something waits -- patiently, it seems -- for the wrong person to say the wrong thing at the right time.
Try me if you want to, Santana.
This is not that time.
Arms all ink and muscle, Prince turns from the urinal, his LEFT HAND BANDAGED, holding a cup of what can only be piss.
He hands it to SHAVONNE BISHOP (30), black, and a lot more battle-ready than her Louboutins would indicate.
Couple more minutes, you'da got a first-class ticket back.
Prince follows her around a maze of cubicles, where suited types confer with various other men and the occasional woman.
Can't go when somebody's looking, Ma'am. S'all I'm saying.
And what, I get a kick out of watching a grown man pee?
Prince tries to get comfortable in the stiff, utilitarian chair. Across the desk, Bishop gathers paperwork.
I don't even pop Tylenol, Ma'am.
Prince flexes his bandaged hand, takes in the wall decor:
TEMPLE DIPLOMA, A LITANY OF COMMENDATIONS AND KUDOS...
Tylenol's okay. Stay away from poppy seeds. They test dirty.
ASSORTED PHOTOS OF BISHOP WITH IMPORTANT-LOOKING FOLK...
What'd you do to your hand?
AND THE REQUISITE FAMILY SHOT: HUSBAND, TWO KIDS.
Santana.
He jolts back from sightseeing to find her zeroed in on him.
What took you so long to come in?
They told me I had seventy-two hours --
From Allenwood to your permanent residence? That's three hours, tops.
No reply. Just that same cold stare.
You gonna give me problems, Santana?
Before he can even --
'Cause you can save me the paperwork. I'll violate your ass right now and we can try this again next year.
And for the first time, Prince smiles. He holds her gaze a beat, then looks up at the CIRCULAR PLAQUE on the wall:
U.S. PROBATION OFFICE - PENNSYLVANIA EASTERN DISTRICT
What's funny?
Nothing, Ma'am.
She reads his eyes for any hint of smart-ass. Satisfied that she's found none, she gets back to the file folder.
I won't ask what kept you so busy for three days. Thirteen years is a long time. Let's assume whatever it was, you got it out your system.
Uniformed girls spill out of the building.
PRINCE -- SANS BANDAGE, watches from across the street.
He sees someone, tosses his Newport. Checks his reflection in a car window, then crosses, so he can catch up to --
FOUR LATINA STUDENTS, chirping away the day's gossip.
S'cuse me, ladies.
They turn, give him that "fuck off" look natural to teenage girls -- except for REYNA (16 almost), who's caught off guard.
Way off guard.
Another girl, DANIELLE (16 already), no such problem.
Excuse you. (off Reyna) What, you know him or something?
Prince gives her a polite smile, but his focus remains on --
He's... He's my father.
The girls ooh and aah. They've heard...
Thought you was locked up -- (off Reyna's react) What. S'true, ain't it?
Aiight if I walk with you?
Reyna hesitates. Danielle grabs Prince's arm --
C'mon, Papi, we'll walk with you.
Reyna's glare freezes Danielle in her tracks. Danielle giggles, lets go of Prince, hurries the other girls ahead.
Prince studies his daughter. She studies the pavement.
You're tall.
She responds with a half smile.
How'd you recognize me?
I dunno... My mom had a few pictures.
Yeah...? How's she doing, your mom?
She aiight.
How about her, ummm --
My dad?
A beat.
Yeah.
She shrugs. They walk a few steps. Silent. Awkward.
School going okay?
Another shrug. A few more steps. A little more silence.
How long you been back?
Couple of hours, maybe.
And you came straight here --?
JAVAN (O.S.) YO, REYNA!
JAVAN MIRABAL, 17, Dominican, rock-hard stare, leans out of a tuned-up import. Red rosary beads around his neck.
Lemme talk to you --Leave me alone, Javan.
Can I just talk to --Can you just leave me alone?
Prince stares, waiting. Javan notices. Stares right back. This kid does not spook easy...
Just go already!
Javan finally breaks eye contact. Revs the engine. PEELS off.
That your boyfriend?
One more shrug.
He always yell at you like that?
Reyna looks across the street, sees a tricked-out SUV playing LOUD HIP-HOP. Danielle and her friends trade flirty poses with a pair of THUGS-IN-TRAINING, one of who rolls a blunt.
I gotta go.
She walks away. He realizes this is all he's gonna get -- he digs a few bills out his pocket, offers them to her.
Hold up...
Naw, you don't gotta --
Get yourself something nice, aiight? Some sneakers or something.
She hesitates --
He pecks her on the cheek, awkward. She takes the money, half smiles, walks away. He watches as she and her friends drive off, Danielle in back, talking with her hands at Reyna.
If asked, he would swear his little girl is crying.
Someone passes the now lit blunt to Reyna. Danielle declines for her. And like a good BFF, she wipes her friend's tears.
You gotta tell him.
I ain't gotta do shit. Fuck him.
The SUV THUMP-THUMPS down Lehigh Ave, drives by a schoolyard whose main wall is decorated with --
AN OLD, FADED GRAFFITI MURAL.
Not the flash-art downtown kind that caters to college kids and drunk bride-to-be's. This one shares the block with a liquor store, an immigration lawyer and a Chinese take-out.
Per the SIGN, this is the place to get your very own --
Prince sits, shirtless, lost in the early 90s SEATTLE GRUNGE wafting in the background. He stares at the wall-to-wall PHOTOS OF MULTI-FLAVORED AND MONOCHROMATIC TATTOOS.
But one particular PHOTO holds his attention --
Five teenage boys, mean-mugging in front of that same SCHOOLYARD MURAL when it was brand new. It reads: LA COSA.
All the boys Latino. All of them bling'd out in gold chains. And all of them with enough ammo to attack a small country.
See your P.O. yet?
Prince turns to face LUCKY (32), Puerto Rican, wheelchair, who smooths Saran Wrap on the just-finished tat along Prince's rib cage. Six others already on his chiseled torso.
Lucky checks the plastic, wheels backwards, satisfied. Prince puts his shirt on. Gazes around the shop --
Slow day. A pierced-up BODY PIERCER reads a newspaper.
A pair of 'round-the-way HONEYS wince as their HOMEGIRL (19) gets a flock of butterflies buzzed onto her neck.
And a four-deep crew of TEENAGED LATINO HARDROCKS, peruse an artist's portfolio for ideas. Each one wears some item or other -- beads, bandanna, baseball cap -- of red.
Got a nice spot here, Lucky. I'm glad to see you kept drawing.
On one wall, graffiti art frames a PORTRAIT of a smiling high- school grad. A stylized 'Rest in Peace, Papo' adorns the bottom.
Kinda tricky doing walls in this.
Prince takes in Lucky and his wheelchair.
My moms got the money you and Primo sent. Really touched her, man, how you all came through -- shit, me too.
Must've been some bomb, homie.
R.P.G., actually. Some dustbowl called Anbar I had no desire to visit.
(re: his new tat) So what I owe you?
For that? S'nothing.
Prince ignores him, digs in his pocket --
C'mon, Prince. Love is love. I owe you a lot more than a free tattoo.
A beat.
That was a long time ago, homie.
Fuck that. (re: the RIP mural) Last I heard, the boys who put my little brother on that wall are still buried.
Prince glances around, edgy someone might've caught that, but... No. Everyone's in their own world. That is, except -- one of the young Hardrocks makes eye contact. Holds it.
S'up, dawg? You aiight?
Prince looks around, not sure if --
You, nigga. You know me or something?!
That alerts everyone in the shop, especially the other Hardrock kids, who shift their attention to --
Prince -- cool, calm and... smiling?
Yo, fall back, youngboy. Know who that is you talking to?
Give a fuck! You know who I am?!
Who are you, nigga?
CHICKY MORALES (31), Puerto Rican, enters. Smartly dressed, and not a big guy by any stretch, but he walks it like he talks it. And so far, that's been more than enough.
Behind him comes FLACO (30), chunky, the total opposite of his name -- and not to be confused for a lightweight. Ever.
Can' hear you, dawg.
The Hardrock thinks about saying something -- thinks better of it. No help from his cronies, either.
(re: Prince) I know this man. He's my brother.
The Hardrock averts Chicky's eyes.
Wanna throw up signs and rock beads 'n shit, but don't know your own family. This man put in work -- real muthafuckin' work -- for you to walk around waving that flag.
Chicky, man --
Hold up, Prince -- (to the Hardrock) Take them fuckin' colors off.
(sotto, to his homies) Oh shit, that's Prince? My brother used to talk about all the --
Who's your brother, dawg?
Ammo. He used to roll with the --
Ammo?! That nigga's a bitch. Take your colors off too, fuck that. Probably got bitch in your DNA. (thinks, decides) Matter fact, all of you. Off.
The Hardrocks look around at each other, helpless --
CHICKY S'GO! WHAT THE FUCK!
-- and finally lift beads from necks, bandannas from pockets.
What's the name of this family?
Again, the Hardrock kid hesitates.
Gotta be kidding me --We don't have one.
They turn to see ELLI, the girl with the neck tat in-progress, her hand raised like she's in class. Chicky glares at the Hardrock before asking her --
What's your name, mami?
Elli... I know who you are.
Aiight, Elli, explain to these youngboys why the family got no name.
'Cause we don't need one. (off Chicky's prompt) 'Cause a name means you can be compared to somebody else. There ain't no other family but La Cosa.
She throws the LC gang sign up, both hands.
'Train a child in the way he should go, and when he is old, he shall not depart from it.' -- Or she. (to Lucky) Her tat's on me. Her girls, too. (to the Hardrock crew) The fuck out. Beat it.
Damn, Uncle Chicky --
Now you wanna say something? Be out, before I really embarrass you.
The No-Longer-So-Hard Hardrocks exit. Chicky squares on Prince --
Ain't been out a few hours and already you in some shit.
Neither man moves. Neither one blinks. Lucky, Flaco, the tat artists, Elli and her girls, all tense --
But Chicky cracks up laughing. Bear hugs his old friend.
Y'all dudes do not change, man.
New import. Requisite crucifix hangs from the rearview. Flaco drives. Chicky's shotgun, on his cell. Prince puffs a Newport, watches nighttime North Philly roll by his window.
L.E.D., right? I can't do shit with old school plasmas.
Early out, so the bodegas are still open. And the bars, well, around here, gentrification's a few more years and a lot less yearly homicides away, so the bars stay open.
Mamis are out tonight, dawg.
Teenage moms on rowhouse steps watch their babies learn the social skills that'll help them survive out here.
Don' worry, Prince, we got a couple smuts lined up for you.
Grandmothers in their 30s watch the babies of those who didn't.
I already got 'em sold. Tell him to pull the fuckin' trigger already.
Chicky clicks off, sees Prince staring out the window at --
A ghostly pale NEON CROSS flickering above a doorway.
The Holy Tabernacle of Our Lord's Sacred Heart -- i.e. one of those hopelessly outmatched church-ettes that might rescue a few souls, but against an entire neighborhood? Forget it.
SINGING and the jingle of TAMBOURINES seep through the door.
Prince and Chicky exit the car. Flaco stays behind. Prince tosses his cigarette, goes to enter, but Chicky stops him --
One thing. Our boy in there? Don't forget who he used to be. Aiight?
Thirty or so CHURCHGOERS, lost in hyper-worship.
Leading the flock is DANTE NAVARRO (34), Puerto Rican. Not exactly the seminary school type, his cheap suit and tie in sharp contrast to the teardrop tats and wicked eyebrow scar.
He notices Prince and Chicky by the entrance. Smiles broadly, exchanges an unspoken "S'up", but keeps singing until --
The song ends. Now come hugs and "God bless you's" all around. Dante works his way through the congregation toward Chicky and Prince, who looks up, smiles. But not because of Dante --
ALMA SANTANA (65) approaches. In another place, she'd be the matriarch of a glorious bloodline. In North Philly, she's --
Wela. [Grandma]
He hugs her, tight. She, not quite so. He pulls away, beaming, this reunion unexpected -- but not at all like he daydreamed.
What are you doing here?
I... I just came home today, Wela.
Asi me'ntere. [So I heard] But what are you doing here?
Chicky takes Alma's hand, kisses it.
We came to see you, Doña. [Madam]
Hmph. You still embarrassing your mother's memory, Bienvenido? Or did you get your common sense back?
Enough to make sure you're the only one who calls me 'Bienvenido,' Doña.
(to Prince) And you? You finally ready to be saved?
Wouldn't be the first miracle.
Prince turns to find Dante, then strong handshakes and hugs.
A pastor. I heard about it, but I didn't believe it.
Aaah, I'm nobody special, bro. The Lord calls each and every one of us. (MORE)
It's up to you to answer the phone.
What if you run out of minutes?
Show some respect, Bienvenido.
The Lord blesses all of us with unlimited calling plans, bro. You're here tonight 'cause Jesus has your cell number.
Prince chuckles, until he realizes --
I'm serious, bro. I been where you been -- both of you -- running the streets, doing the devil's work.
I hear you --Be quiet and listen.

Do you hear me, bro? I know you since we were kids. Always trying to be like Primo, even before La Cosa. (to Chicky) And what about you? And Joe-Joe? What'd that get us? To fight? To sell drugs and shoot people --
Yo, fall back, nigga --Bienvenido.
S'aiight, hermana, sometimes I get carried away by the Spirit and I can't stop talking.
Chicky smirks. Dante doesn't catch it -- Prince does.
I'm not gonna stop talking to Jesus until you come home, Prince.
Sure it's him you been talking to?
Bienvenido, that's enough!
Chicky and Dante lock eyes for a beat. They laugh, but -- Prince can't help notice Dante laughs a little too hard.
Dant', let me take my grandma home. I haven't seen her in a while.
I wanna see you here tomorrow, don't front -- Hermana, bring him with you.
Alma regards her grandson, no approval. Dante hugs Prince --
I love you, brothers --
Reaches out to include Chicky.
-- but Jesus loves you even more. And his clique runs a lot deeper than we ever did.
An enormous "Last Supper" dominates the wall.
You're not going to live forever, you know, you and your friends.
Dusty SPORTS TROPHIES line the wall unit -- girl's softball, volleyball, track.
No matter the money, the women, all these things of the world --
Prince looks at all the PHOTOS on the bookshelves, the walls. A few are SCHOOL PORTRAITS of him.
We all fall short.
The rest are a GIRL at various stages: Pigtails in elementary. A cutie in junior high. Athletic in high school.
All of us. Except our Lord and Savior, who died on the cross that we may have eternal life in heaven.
Alma enters, sips from a coffee cup. She fingers the SMALL, DIAMOND-FILLED CROSS around her neck.
This is your resurrection, Prince. Do some good with your new life.
ISABEL SANTANA (49), Prince's mother, the GIRL in Alma's photos, now handsome if not beautiful, enters with a plate of rice, beans and pork chops.
Sets it on the table in front of Prince, who digs right in.
How long's it been you had chuletas? I know them jailbirds can't throw down like Mami.
He mumbles a mouth full of agreement, but --
I ain't gonna lie, Ma. There was this one gump, who used to --
One what?
S'what D.C. boys call the gay dudes.
So say that, then.
Cuban guy from New York. Cooking skills were some whole other level.
Hmph. Better than mine?
He smiles, better to leave that one right there.
Fuck you, then.
He chuckles. Even after all these years -- same ol' mom.
Wait -- I know you wasn't in there messin' with no faggots, were you?
Been watching too many prison flicks, Ma.
She heads toward the kitchen -- stops.
The fuck you just say to me?
Nothing, Ma, just... What.
Watch how you fuckin' talk to me, is what. I don't give a fuck how long you was locked up. I'll still bust ya ass up and down this house.
Yeah. Same ol' mom.
God, you starting with him already?
MAGGIE ORTIZ (38), the former neighborhood teen-queen in a valiant fight to keep her crown, glides in with a TODDLER.
What, no hug?
She wraps herself all over Prince.
Aiight, shit, don't suffocate him.
Maggie, wow... Look at you. (re: the tot) This the grandson?
Ugh. He calls me 'Mami.' I'm way too young to be nobody's grandmother.
Bitch, you ain't that young.
Maggie slaps Isabel's arm, apparently used to it.
Still can't believe Jasmine's old enough to have a kid. How's she doing?
Hmph. I'm watching her kid. (to Isabel, re: Prince) God, lookit him, Ma. He was a baby when he went away.
Fuckin' punk, is what he was, him and all his knucklehead friends. Acting tough when they ain't even know how to wipe they ass.
Don't listen to her, baby. You was always mature for your age. And cute.
Isabel goes into the kitchen --
Guess who I saw today, Ma.
One of your knucklehead friends.
Besides them. I went to see Dante. He's a pastor now, believe that? (beat) Wela was there. She goes to his church.
Nothing. He looks to Maggie, who wants no part of it.
Ma, you heard me? I saw Wela.
Isabel walks back in from the kitchen. Gives him a dead stare.
Who?
C'mon, Ma --
Fuck her. (smiles, back to work) Want some coffee?
And that settles that. Prince checks his watch. Gets up --
I'ma take a walk, look around --
You ain't been out a few hours and already you wanna get in some shit?
Just a few people I gotta see, Ma.
See about getting a job. Something. Not chasing after so-called friends who never gave a fuck about you.
He gives her a half smile. Knew that was coming.
Oooh, look at his face, Ma. He ain't gonna go see his friends. He probably got some chick waiting to give him some.
He ignores that. Gives his mother a peck on the cheek. Awkward, like he was with Reyna. Isabel's just as stiff.
What, no kiss for me? Or you so backed up you scared you'll bust in your pants?
Watch it, bitch. You cuttin' it close.
She grabs Maggie's belt, pulls her in, playful. They kiss.
Yeah, that kind of kiss.
Prince pretends to busy himself with the plate of leftovers. Maggie pulls away from Isabel, turns to him.
Wow, Ma... Look at all this ink.
She runs a manicured fingernail along Prince's right forearm, specifically, the intricate TATTOO of:
A WOMAN SHROUDED IN A PUERTO RICAN FLAG, WEARING A CROWN OF THORNS, HER SWORD RAISED HIGH.
Who's this supposed to be?
Prince, LEFT HAND BANDAGED, leans forward, arms outstretched, as Bishop snaps pictures of his tats with a digital camera.
S'nobody special.
She stares, waits.
Saw it in a magazine. Let this Mexican dude Smiley do his thing with it.
Really. Next you're gonna tell me it's religious.
Watching too many prison flicks, Ma'am.
You're older than me, so knock it off with all that 'Ma'am' nonsense.
She stops taking pictures. Stares right through him.
Let me make this easy for you, Santana. I can send you back for lying to me. And I know all about La Cosa.
She waits. He says nada. She snaps a few more pics.
Might wanna think about wearing long sleeves to job interviews, you plan on using your degree.
An Associate's? That's like a G.E.D. with fancier calligraphy.
Hell of an attitude towards education.
Gave me something to do besides work out and play cards. Can't do much with a 'Management' degree, anyway.
You can get a job with it.
I got thirteen years of UNICOR pay saved up till I find something.
So find something. You can't be gallivanting around all day with nothing to do but look pretty.
She glances over at his file --
Restitution's paid up. Good.
That's 'cause the D.E.A. took most of it in cash.
He smiles. She doesn't.
Yeah, well, you and your L.C. boys lived the life a long time, Santana --
Typical mayhem of another day at school. Girls rush to class. Reyna, Danielle and company prolong the inevitable.
-- somebody had to pay for it.
Sweatergod, if I take one more Religion class, I'ma convert to Buddhism. That shit's easy.
Maybe in your next life you won't be so slutty.
Oh em gee, bitch!
They crack up, but... Reyna's smile fades as they look --
ACROSS THE STREET -
Javan gets out of his car, heads straight for them. Reyna hurries to the doors. Danielle steps in his path.
S'way too early for this shit, yo.
(ignores her) C'mon, Rey, let me holla at you.
Won't you go holla at your little Dominican smut on Howard Street?
He shoves Danielle aside. Runs to catch up to --
REYNA I GOT NOTHING TO SAY TO YOU!
She stomps inside the school just as he gets there.
Rey..! REY..! REYNA -- GODDAMMIT!
He fumes there a beat. Wary students give him plenty of room. He walks to his car, stares daggers at Danielle the entire way.
Need to mind ya business.
I love you too, bitch-ass.
Isabel, in hospital scrubs, busies herself with coffee. Maggie, receptionist-casual, scrapes a piece of toast.
I hate when you do that.
I don't like it burnt.
So leave the toaster on '3.' Now you got crumbs all over the fuckin' sink.
Ugh. Tough night at work, whatthefuck?
Prince enters. From the look of his sweats, right after a serious workout. Isabel smiles. Maggie too, but... different.
You hungry? I'll make some eggs.
Naw, get some sleep, Ma. I'll just --
Boy, shut up and eat something.
Take advantage. She's in a great mood.
Aiight... How 'bout some egg whites?
Lookitchu, trying to eat all healthy.
Isabel grabs eggs and other items from the fridge.
Mind if I get some orange juice, Ma?
Papi, cut that shit out already. This is your house.
And that settles that. Prince pours some OJ, downs it.
I'ma jump in the shower.
He exits.
I better get going, too.
Maggie places her dish in the sink. Pecks Isabel on the lips. Goes through a few ready-to-leave motions --
Damn, I forgot my phone.

blocks.location: ISABEL'S HOUSE. PRINCE'S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER

blocks.text: Prince, naked but for a towel, checks the plastic on his tat. Satisfied, he grabs his toiletries. Goes to open the door --
But it opens first -- Maggie, no shame in her game.
I didn't hear you get in last night -- Oooh, you got a new tattoo already?
She moves closer to him. A little too close.
You look good, baby. You really took care of yourself in there.
Maggie --These little girls out here are gonna tear ya ass up.
Maggie, look, I appreciate you writing to me. Your letters always made me --
Your phone was in your purse.
Prince almost jumps out his skin as Maggie spins to see --
ISABEL -- Rachael Ray-smile gone. She hands Maggie her cell.
Jasmine called. It was in your purse.
(recovers...barely) Thanks, Ma. Prince was showing me the new tat he just got. (to Prince) Looks nice.
She squeezes by Isabel on her way out.
Love you, Ma. I'll call you later.
Prince pretends to gather his toiletries. Isabel glares at him. Ice-hot. Finally, she exits.
Prince, showered and dressed, enters. He pours a glass of OJ. Grabs a plate and fork, goes to the stove to get --
WHAT USED TO BE EGGS. Burnt to carbon, shells and all.
He takes a breath. Resigned. Like he knew it was coming.
He scrapes the blackened eggs into the garbage disposal. Squeezes dishwashing liquid into the pan. Lets the faucet run, and watches as the water spills over the sides.
He goes to sip his OJ. Stops. Pours it down the drain instead.
Prince passes Isabel, still in her scrubs, stretched out on the couch, staring at the women of The View on television.
You should get some sleep, Ma.
(eyes on the TV) Better think about doing something with your fuckin' life. Ain't no free rides in my world.
He stares at his mother a beat. Exits.
Alma descends her front steps, shopping cart in tow.
She sees her NEIGHBOR (70s), being helped onto a SENIOR CITIZEN PARATRANSIT VAN by the DRIVER (40s). She waves hello. Her Neighbor and the Driver wave back.

Dante steps out the cab of a tricked-out flatbed tow truck. The logo says it's from DIAMOND TOWING. He looks up at the driver, WEESO (23), Puerto Rican. Not the guy you want to run into in the middle of the night.
Coming by later, right?
I'll see w'sup.
C'mon, Weeso. Bring your wife and the baby. They'll enjoy it, I promise.
I'll see w'sup, Pápa. No lie.
(smiles, knows it is) Just like your father, boy.

blocks.location: FRONT STREET. EL TRAIN - MOVING - DAY

blocks.text: The elevated Market-Frankford line snakes its way above the down-and-out stores and empty lots along Front Street.
From here looking west, this "City of Neighborhoods" gets dissected by impossibly narrow one-way streets, packed with block after block of neat, seemingly cozy rowhouses.
In the distance, William Penn watches over his beloved settlement from his hundred-year old post atop City Hall.
As the El runs parallel to the I-95, Prince looks out the window at the BILLBOARDS proclaiming --
-- FLY, EAGLES, FLY!
-- THE PENNSYLVANIA LOTTERY IS NOW AT 90 MILLION!
and... -- FIND YOUR BABY'S DADDY, CALL 1-800-DNA-TEST!
Prince takes in Philly's hipster haunt, replete with pre- planned dive bars and shops selling T's with ironic slogans.
Gazes at a few displays showcasing the latest high-end sneakers, urban couture and all its blingy accoutrements.
Stares at a street hawker's wares: "City of Brotherly Thugs" hats, tees and other non-Chamber of Commerce-approved goods.
Stops at a window flaunting all the techno-magic that has become the consumer electronics game.
A CLERK watches and waits as Prince studies an iPhone, completely, unequivocally, without a doubt -- lost.
And a fifteen-year old's gonna know how to work one of these?
The clerk stares at him -- tats, Dickies -- like he just recognized him from an episode of COPS.
